results.title: A room for Romeo Brass
results.creator_credit: Alliance Atlantis, BBC Film Unit, George Faber, Charles Pattinson and Shane Meadows
results.brief_description: Shane Meadows writes and directs this drama about two young boys’ friendship and their coming-of-age. Neighbours, the boys share life experiences (and porno magazines) and support each other as one is physically unwell and the other’s parents have separated. The friendship is tested however when a creepy stranger manipulates his way into their lives by trying to date the attractive older sister of Romeo. Tensions arise as the stranger becomes more violent as his affections are rejected. Touching, funny and disturbing, this feature stars Paddy Considine as the stranger, with wonderful performances by the two young leads Andrew Shim and Ben Marshall. Bob Hoskins makes an appearance as a visiting teacher. Soundtrack features music by Beck, Beth Orton and Billy Bragg.

results.title: A roof over your head; Detective work in the woods
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Dandelion = Pusteblume”.
Two episodes of the successful children’s series Pusteblume. “A roof over your head” - People live in houses in order to protect themselves from the wind, rain, heat or cold. Peter Lustig experiences what can happen without a roof over one’s head. In addition, he shows us how people build new houses and how some animals build themselves a hideaway. “Tracks in the wood” - Peter Lustig finds lots of tracks made in the wood by animals who live there. Naturally, he also hears lots of different noises made by animals when they forage for food or creep through the undergrowth. People go into the woods too of course, to collect mushrooms or just to go for a walk. The forest ranger is really cross with those who rubbish the woods and damage the natural environment.

results.title: A Rock climb
results.creator_credit: Boy Scouts of America. Visual Education Service
results.brief_description: The film describes the activities of a rock-climbing Explorer Unit from Phoenix, Arizona - the Kachinas. First their equipment and techniques are demonstrated and then the camera records the actual climb of a sheer peak in the Arizona Desert, a peak never before climbed by man.

results.title: A Road is built
results.brief_description: A study of the use of heavy mechanical equipment during the building of a road in the timber country near Noogee in Victoria. Bulldozers, rooters, power-graders, and heavy earth-moving machines are seen at work as the road takes shape.
results.description: A study of the use of heavy mechanical equipment during the building of a road in the timber country near Noogee in Victoria. Bulldozers, rooters, power-graders, and heavy earth-moving machines are seen at work as the road takes shape.

results.title: A Road in time
results.creator_credit: Brian Bosisto, Brian Bosisto and Associates, South Australian Film Corporation and John Dick
results.brief_description: With an eye to the energy crisis and environmental issues, this film gives a pictorial history of road-building in South Australia. As such, it also encapsulates the economic and urban development of this State. Contains b&w archival footage. Narrated by John Dick.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Brian Bosisto, Brian Bosisto and Associates, South Australian Film Corporation and John Dick

results.title: A River somewhere. - Vol. 1 & 2.
results.creator_credit: Debra Choate, Frontline Television Productions, ABC-TV (Australia), Tom Gleisner and Rob Sitch
results.brief_description: Filmed on location in Australia, New Zealand, Venezuela, Scotland and Italy, Tom Gleisner and Rob Sitch allow their passion for fly fishing to take them around the world, visiting some of the most remote and beautiful waterways. Using a variety of transportation methods including vespa and post van, the two fishermen are determined to catch their dinner and cook it in the local style. “A River somewhere” is a viewing treat and with the wry wit and humour of Sitch and Gleisner, the program is both entertaining and visually breathtaking.

results.title: A River runs through it
results.creator_credit: Allied Filmmakers, Robert Redford and Patrick Markey
results.brief_description: Norman Maclean’s novel has been brought to life under the skillful direction of Robert Redford and fine performances by Tom Skerrit, Brad Pitt and Craig Sheffer. Set in the mountain wilderness of Montana between 1910-1935, the story focuses on the relationship between two brothers. Their upbringing at the hands of their strict missionary father influences the boys to chose different paths. One brother goes down the road to success while the other’s path is filled with trouble and heartbreak. The two brothers share little in common except their passion for fly fishing which unites them.

results.title: A Right to refuse?
results.creator_credit: Clayton Bailey, Caroline Leaf, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “People at Work”.
Dramatization of an industrial conflict. Workers should realise that they have the right to refuse to do jobs under dangerous or unhealthy conditions.

results.title: A Return to the Rocks
results.creator_credit: David Beal, Audience Motivation, Sydney Cove Redevelopment Authority and John Fitzgerald
results.brief_description: The history of Sydney Cove and the Rocks area, shown by means of sketches, paintings, photographs and dramatisations. The Sydney Cove Redevelopment Authority has been set up to preserve the unique character of the area. Shows some of the Australia Day celebrations at the birth place of the nation. Narrated by Peter Gwynne and Tim Eliott. Written by David Whitaker. Cinematography John Fitzgerald, Oscar Scherl, Ian Stock and Foster Stubbs.

results.title: A Research brief. No. 3
results.creator_credit: Dumont Film Productions, ONF | NFB and John McAulay
results.brief_description: The film records projects undertaken by the National Research Council of Canada - the launching of helium balloons to measure the ozone layer, cloud seeding to help fight forest fires, a study of the Gaspe current, recommendations to alleviate the St. Laurence Seaway Bottleneck, helicopter transport of trees out of logging sites and the feasibility of rockets to carry scientific instruments into the heart of the aurora borealis.
